column1: Does the country have an income tax treaty with the U.S.
column8: Yes; however, may not be available for the chief officer of the representative office in China.

column1: Does country recognize Economic Employer Concept
column12: No - Finnish tax authorizes normally look at who is the legal employer. However, there are no written guidelines regarding this issue.
column13: No - however there is a trend towards taking the economic employer approach where there is a recharge of the remuneration costs to the French entity.
column18: No - but Revenue may review this position in the future
column31: Yes - position has not been established but official clarifications of the Russian financial and tax authorities as well as court practice do use this approach. 60 days before the local tax authority will apply to economic employer approach.
column33: No - position has not been established
column38: Yes - 60 days before the local tax authority will apply to economic employer approach.

column1: How is the treaty applied? (i.e., 60, 90, 120 or 183 days)
column21: 183 days AND remuneration not to exceed $3,000

column1: How is the 183-day or other rule for employment services applied? (i.e., on a calendar year, fiscal year, rolling 12 month period, or other)
If the treaty applies, is a return or other filing required to claim the treaty benefits?
column29: No - however, a tax treaty relief application process should be complied with.

column1: Deminimus # of days present in Host Country that will trigger a tax liability (no treaty)
column23: Tax due based on taxable income
column40: Tax due based on taxable income.

column1: What is the procedure for filing tax returns (i.e., on a calendar year, fiscal year, monthly, or other)
column6: No annual personal income tax filing requirement. Only file Tax of Salary monthly
column9: Calendar year, annual return may not be required for nonresidents if tax is withheld via payroll.

column1: What is the procedure for paying taxes if tax filing and payment obligations are triggered (i.e., monthly, quarterly, annually, or with the return)
column2: Salary subject to withholding at source bu the employer on a regular basis. Tax return to be submitted on annual taxable income by April 15 of the year following the tax year.
column3: Salary paid in Australia subject to monthly PAYG; Salary paid outside of Australia due upon assessment.
column4: Salary subject to withholding at source by the employer on a regular basis. Final tax payment should be made within two months of the date of the final tax assessment.
column5: Salary subject to withholding tax on salary received in Brazil. Any balance due on the final tax return can be made in a lump sum payment when the return is filed or in eight monthly installments subject to interest.
column6: Salary subject to monthly tax withholdings via payroll.
column7: Tax withholding must be reported, withheld and remitted each pay period by employers unless a waiver of withholding has been issued by CRA. Tax returns are due by April 30 of the following year. Any tax liability must be paid by April 30 to avoid penalties and interest.
column8: Monthly tax return must be filed with the PRC IIT along with tax liability due.  Annual returns may be due if taxed on a worldwide basis.
column9: Monthly withholding via payroll.  If nonresidents pay tax via payroll withholdings an annual return may not be required.  For nonresidents who do not have tax withholding an annual returns is required and a tax advance for the following year is required.
column10: Monthly withholding via payroll based on pre-printed tax card as issued by the tax authorities. Nonresident individuals do not receive a pre-printed tax assessment.
column11: No Income Tax Liability in UAE
column12: Monthly withholding based on employee's tax card. If nonresident, may have tax-at-source card which indicates a 35% withholding. If employer does not have a permanent establishment and is not registered as an employer with the tax authorities, a resident employee working in Finland has to contact the local tax office for instructions on how to pay withholding tax themself.
column13: There is no withholding in France for resident taxpayers. Employer required to withhold tax when a nonresident received compensation that is taxable in France. The employer must file a monthly withholding tax return. Final tax liability for prior year is either paid in three installments or 10 monthly payments. Final tax payment is due on September 15 after the actual assessment is received.
column14: Salary subject to monthly tax withholdings via payroll and assessment notice upon filing of tax return for any residual balance due.
column15: Estimates based on prior year paid in based on following percentages: Q4 (Fiscal year) – 75% & After Year-End – 25%.  Final assessment paid with next years 75% provisional tax.
column16: Salary subject to monthly tax withholdings via payroll.
column17: Salary subject to monthly tax withholdings via payroll
column18: Salary subject to monthly tax withholdings via payroll.
column19: Compensation is subject to monthly withholding tax when paid by Italian employers. For non-Italian employers, income taxes are to be paid by the employees in two installments. By June 16 of each year, the taxpayer must pay the balance for the previous tax year and the first advance payment for the current tax year. The first payment is 39.6% of the taxes paid for the previous tax year. The second installment, equal to the remaining 59.4 percent of the taxes paid for the previous tax year, is due by November 30.
column20: Compensation is subject to withholding if paid to a resident or nonresident from an onshore employer. Compensation paid to a nonresident from an entity not resident in Japan but have an office or place of business in Japan, the office or place of business in Japan is required to withhold income tax on the payments. Provisional national tax payments are based on the prior year's tax liability and is payable in two equal installments.
column21:
Class A Income (employment income from Korean entity) is subject to monthly tax withholdings via payroll.
Class B Income (employment income from foreign entity) is subject to an annual return due during May of the following year and annual tax liability is due with the filing of that return.
column22: Salary subject to monthly tax withholdings via payroll.
column23: Salary subject to monthly tax withholdings via payroll
column24: Salary subject to monthly tax withholdings via payroll
column25: Salary subject to monthly tax withholdings via payroll
column26: Salary subject to monthly tax withholdings via payroll (PAYE)
column27: Salary paid in New Zealand subject to monthly PAYE; Salary paid outside of New Zealand due upon assessment
column28: Salary subject to withholding via payroll. Withheld taxes are submitted to the tax collector on a bi-monthly basis. Withholding is based on a tax card obtained by the employee from the local tax office. Any balance due of taxes will be due once the individual receives their tax assessment.
column29: Salary subject to monthly tax withholdings via payroll
column30: Salary subject to monthly tax withholdings via payroll
column31: Tax Returns must be filed by all resident and nonresident individuals who have at least one source of income subject to tax in the Russian Federation on which income tax has not been witheld by a tax agent. If a foreign Individual ceases during a calendar year to engage in activities that generate taxable income in the Russian Federation, and then leaves the Russian Federation, that individual must submit a departure declaration no later than one month before the individual leaves the Russian Federation. Tax due on the departure tax declaration must be paid no later than 15 days after the declaration is submitted.
column32: Assessment based.  Pay prior year tax liability in current year through one time payment or installments of maximum 12 months.
column33: Salary subject to withholdings via payroll. Employer must file monthly or quarterly withholding returns.
column34: Salary paid by resident employers is subject to withholding based on a tax bill issued by the tax agency. Salary paid by nonresident employers is not subject to withholding. Instead, the employee may apply for a Special A-tax bill and make estimated payments on a monthly basis.
column35: Salary subject to monthly tax withholdings via payroll
column36: Tax Liability paid with annual tax return. Taiwan employer must withhold tax payable at the time of payment.
column37: Salary subject to withholding via payroll each payment (bi-weekly, monthly, etc.)
column38: Salary subject to monthly tax withholdings via payroll
column40: Salary subject to monthly tax withholdings via payroll

column1: Does the country have a Social Security Totalization Agreement with the U.S.
column16: No, social security is generally assessed.  Some exceptions do apply.
column31: No  - However, earnings of Highly Qualified Specialists are not subject to Russian Social Fund Contributions. In additionan, employees who are foreign nationals are only subject to pension fund contributions.

column22: Yes - however, the economic employer approach may complicate the application of the treaty.

column1: When is an individual taxed as a resident vs. nonresident?
column2: A resident is subject to tax on worldwide income.  A nonresident is subject to income tax only only income received from Armenian sources.  A person is considered a resident if he or she resides in Armenia for 183 or more cumulative days in any continuous 12-month period ending in the current tax year (same as calendar year) OR his or her center of vital interests (place of a person’s family or economic interests) is in Armenia.
column3: Residency rules very complex.  Determined on case by case basis.
column4: Taxable as a resident if domiciled in Belgium or who manage their wealth from Belgium. Residency status is determined based on the facts and circumstances. If can individual is enrolled in the National Register of the Population are presumed to be resident. Residents tax on worldwide income, nonresidents taxed on Belgian source income.
column5:
Resident taxpayers include the following:
- naturalized foreigners
- foreigners, holders of permanent visa (since they arrive in Brazil)
- foreigners, holders of temporary visa with a local employment contract, arriving in Brazil, since the date of arrival
- foreigners, holders of temporary visa without a local employment contract, arriving in Brazil after completing 183 days of stay in Brazil, counted within any 12-month period. 
Nonresidents are foreigners, holders of temporary visa without an employment contract with a local company, arriving in Brazil, before completing 183 days of stay in Brazil, counted within any 12-month period. Residents taxed on worldwide income, nonresidents taxed on Brazilian source income, subject to flat withholding at 25%.
column6: Taxable as resident if domiciled, principal place of abode in Cambodia or present for more than 182 days.  Residents taxed on worldwide salary, nonresidents taxed on Cambodian source only.
column7: There are no specific Canadian tax rules for determining whether an individual is resident in Canada. Residency is determined based on facts and circumstances. Residents taxed on worldwide income, nonresidents taxed on Canadian source income.
column8: Taxable as resident if domiciled, or in the first full year after a 5 year residency period, the individual may be taxed on worldwide income.  The first full year is triggered if the individual is not absent from China for more than 30 days in any one trip or 90 days cumulative in 1 year.
column9: Taxable as resident if they reside for more than 6 consecutive or nonconsecutive months in the tax year or if they complete a consecutive 6 month period during a tax year.  However, foreign residents are subject to tax on their Colombian source income during their first 4 years of continuous or discontinuous residence.  They are subject to worldwide tax in their 5th year.
column10: Taxable as a resident if they have a home in Denmark where they live or if they stay in Denmark for at least six consecutive months. Short stays abroad for leisure or holiday will not interrupt the six-month period. Residents taxed on worldwide income, nonresidents taxed on Danish source income.
column12: Taxable as a resident if they have a permanent home in Finland or if they stay in Finland for at least six consecutive months. Temporary absences (up to two months) will not interrupt the six-month period. Residents taxed on worldwide income, nonresidents taxed on Danish source income.
column13: Taxable as resident if domiciled in France. Residents taxed on worldwide income, nonresidents tax on French source income.
column14: Taxable as a resident on worldwide income if present for an uninterrupted period of six months.  Non-resident taxable on only German source income.
column16: Taxable as resident on worldwide income if present in India for 182 days or more in the tax year, however may qualify as taxable on only India source income as "Not Ordinarily Resident (NOR)" if employee has not been an Indian resident in 9 out of 10 tax years or has been present for less than 729 days in the 7 previous tax years.
column17: Taxed as resident if present for more than 183 days in 12 month period. If in calendar tax year reside in Indonesia with intent to stay or meet the time requirements of applicable treaty.
column18:
Taxable as resident if any of the following conditions are met:
- individual spends 183 or more days in Ireland during the calendary year
- individual spends an aggregate of 280 or more days in Irelands during the current and prior tax year, with more than 30 days in Ireland in each tax year
- individual elects to become tax resident for the tax year in which they come to Ireland with the intention to be resident in the following tax year, and is tax resident under one of the tests listed above in the following tax year. 
Residents taxed on worldwide income, nonresidents generally taxed on Irish source income.
column19: Taxable as resident if individual has their habitual abode in Italy or their center of vital interests is located in Italy or they are registered at the Office of Records of the Resident Population in Italy. Residents are taxes on worldwide income and nonresidents are taxes on Italian-source income only.
column20: After one year of residency an individual will be considered a non permanent resident.  After 5 years of residency, permanent resident.  Non residents are taxed at 20% on Japanese source income - national tax only, non permanent residents taxed at regular graduated rates on Japanese source income-national and inhabitants tax, permanent residents taxed on worldwide income at graduated rates. Directors may be taxed differently from non director employees.
column21: Taxable as resident if domiciled or after one year of residency.  A resident is taxed on worldwide income.  A nonresident is taxed on Korean source income.  If the individual maintains resident status in the home country, a determination is made in that country.
column22:
An individual is considered a resident of Luxembourg if his domicile or customary place of abode is in Luxembourg. A person's domicile is the place where he occupies a home under circumstances that indicate he will retain and use it. A customary place of abode is deemed to exist if an individual has been present in Luxembourg for a period of at least 6 months. For short-term assignments, if the individual is considered as resident in both countries, the individual remains resident in the
country where he/she has his/her family and economic links (i.e. center of vital interests). There is no specific consideration for short-term assignments in Luxembourg.
column23: Taxable as resident if they possess an identity card. Non-resident if have a non-resident working permit. There is no distinction between residents and nonresidents for tax purposes.
column24: Taxable as resident if residing for 182 days or more in the year.  If less than 182 in the year, but the period is linked to 182 days or more consecutively immediately preceding or following the calendar year, then residency status is triggered. Income for both residents and nonresidents are taxed on a territorial basis (Malaysian source).
column25:
Short-term assignees could be considered non-residents by not establishing a principal home in Mexico and could be totally exempt of Mexican income taxes when certain conditions are met or
be taxed on lower tax rates on their Mexican-sourced income only. Residents taxable on worldwide income, nonresidents taxable on Mexican source income only.
column26: Residency is determined on the facts of each case. Some considerations are the nature of the stay in the Netherlands, the length of stay, where the family lives, individual's center of economic interest, etc. Residents taxed on worldwide income, nonresidents taxed on Netherlands source income only.
column27: Taxable as resident if they have permanent place of abode in the country or have been personally present for more than 183 days in 12 month period.
column28:
Taxable as resident if any of the follow requirements are met:
- individual stay in Norway for more than 183 days during any 12-month period. Will be resident in the year the requirement is fulfilled.
- individual stays in Norway for more than 270 days during any 36-month period. Will be resident in the year the requirement is fulfilled.
Residents taxed on worldwide income, nonresidents taxed on Norwegian source income only.
column29: Taxable as resident if an individual has indefinite plans to remain.  If the days do not exceed 180 day, then a nonresident not engaged in a trade or business in the Philippines.  If over 180 days, then nonresident engaged in a Philippines trade or business. Nonresidents are taxed based on Philippine source income.
column30: Taxable as resident if place of residence lies within Poland without regards o the location of his center of vital interests. Generally if individual is present in Poland for more than 183 days during the fiscal year (calendar year) they will be considered a tax resident. Residents taxed on worldwide income, nonresidents taxed on Polish source income only.
column31: Individuals are considered a resident if they are present in the country for 183 days or more in a period of 12 consecutive months. Arrival and departure days count as Russian with respect to determining residency.
column32: Taxable as resident if present over 183 days in a tax year and taxed on worldwide income.  Nonresidents between 61 and 183 days taxed on Singapore source income.
column33:
Taxable as resident if any of the following requirements are met:
- individual remains in Spain for more than 183 days in a given calendar year
- individual's business or economic interest are directly or indirectly located within Spanish territory. 
There are certain conditions that an expatriate can meet to be considered a nonresident even if they meet the criteria for being a Spanish tax resident. Residents taxed on worldwide income, nonresidents taxed on Spanish source income and capital gains realized in Spain only.
column34: Taxable as resident if present in Sweden for six months or more and regularly stay overnight. Residents taxed on worldwide income, nonresidents taxed on  Sweden source income only.
column35: Taxable as resident if they take employment for more than 30 consecutive days in country or if they intend to stay permanently.
column36: Taxable as resident if present 183 days or more in a year, if less than 183 days then nonresident.  Both residents and nonresidents are taxed on Taiwan source income.
column37: Taxable as resident if present 180 days or more in any tax year, if less than 180 days then nonresident.  Both residents and nonresidents are taxed on Thailand source income.
column38: Taxable as a resident/not ordinarily resident on UK source income if present more than 183 days in a tax year, but no more than two years in total.
column40: Taxable as resident if present 183 days or more within 12 consecutive month period, if less than 183 days then nonresident.  Reisdents are taxes on worldwide income. Nonresidents are taxes on their Vietnam source income.

column1: How are per diems taxed in the Host Country
column2: Certain conditions apply, but per diems may be excluded from taxable income.
column3: Cash allowances are subject to income tax.  Non-cash allowances are subject to Fringe Benefits Tax (FBT).
column4: Daily allowances (per diems) for long-term foreign business trips are non-taxable. Previous tax exemption was for business trips of 30 days or less. This exemption was extended to longer business trips up to 24 months.
column6: Exempt if qualifies as business expense.
column7: Certain conditions apply, but per diems may be excluded from taxable income.
column8: Per diems are taxable if not evidenced by a receipt. Must qualify as a business expense.
column9: Exempt if qualifies as business expense.
column10: Employer can reimburse either actual costs or provide tax-free per diems for lodging and meals at fixed rates.
column12: If the assignment is deemed as a business trip (determined in the Finnish tax law), travel expenses, daily allowances and housing may be provided exempt of tax.
column13: Tax free reimbursement of certain exempt employment expenses is permitted. Howeve , proof by receipts may be required to sustantiate the expense and to verif it was actually spent in connection with items that would normally be reimbursed free of tax.
column14: Not taxable but with limitations.  Germany has its own per diem guidelines.
column15: Allowances which are reasonable in amount and do no more than cover the employee's travelling, accommodation and related expenses incurred when the employee is working away from their usual base or place of residence as required by their employer is not taxable income.
column16: Cash allowances are taxable.  Housing paid by employer is subject to reduced taxation.
column18: Subsistence allowances are not taxable in Ireland.
column19: Reimbursement of business expenses incurred are not taxable if the expenses are supposed by the origial receipts.
column20: Majority of per diems are taxable. Non-taxable per diems are qualified relcation reimbursements (actual moving cost in connection to the assignees relocation to/from Japan) and transportaion is tax free up to lesser of JPY 100,000 or the actual transportation costs.
column21: Reasonable amount of per diem paid for a short period of assignment which may be treated as a business travel is non-taxable. However, the per diem paid for a long period of assignment is taxable.
column22: Employer can provide luncheon vouchers of a maximum value of EUR 8.40 completely tax free. However, employee is required to pay EUR 2.80 per voucher.
column23: Certain allowances may be nontaxable up to a certain limit.
column24: Travelling allowances in exercising an employment is exempted up to a certain limit per year. Meal allowances given on a daily basis based on a pre-determined rate provided by the employer in a written policy are exempt.
column25: Living expenses from short-term visits to Mexico that are supported by receipts from third parties are free of tax in Mexico. Per diem amounts are treated as a taxable allowance.
column26: Tax free reimbursement of certain employment expenses is permitted.
column28: Tax free if reimbursed for actual expenses. Reimbursements of work-related expenses in excess of actual costs are taxable.
column31: Reimbursements by an employer in Russia of employees' business trips expenses within certain limits, provided these expneses are propery documented in accordance with Russian Legislations, are tax exempt.
column33: Reimbursements of actual expenses are not taxable. Payments for certain business-related expenses are taxable.
column34: Per diems up to a certain standard amount is tax free.
column36: Meal allowance over monthly limit taxable. Daily allowances to individuals hired by a Taiwanese government acency or a private enterprise to provide services in Taiwan and stay for not more than 90 days are exempt from tax up to a certain daily limit.
column37: Per diems are taxable unless the payments represent reimburseable business expenses or transport expenses are exclusively and necessarily incurred in carrying out duties outwide the normal place of work.
column38: Allowances are not taxable if assignment is no more than two years in length.
column40: Per diems are not taxable as long as they are in line with certain regulations.
